<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>15</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869005"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 7. &nbsp;MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The SEC defines critical accounting policies as those that are, in management's view, important to the portrayal of the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations and require management's judgment. &nbsp;The discussion and analysis of the financial condition and results of operations is based on the audited consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (&quot;U.S. GAAP&quot;). &nbsp;The preparation of these financial statements requires the Company to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenue and expenses. &nbsp;Management bases its estimates on experience and on various assumptions that it believes are reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. &nbsp;Actual results may differ from those estimates. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s critical accounting policies include:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Revenue Recognition</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;) Staff Accounting Bulletin 104, &#147;Revenue Recognition&#148;, which requires that: (i) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (ii) delivery has occurred, (iii) the sales price is fixed and determinable, and (iv) collectibility is reasonably assured. The Company recognizes revenue when the building supplies have been shipped.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company also recognizes revenue on a &#147;bill-and-hold&#148; basis in accordance with the authoritative guidance. Under the Company&#146;s &#147;bill-and-hold&#148; arrangements, at the request of the customer, finished inventory is segregated for future delivery at the customer&#146;s discretion. &nbsp;Title and risk of loss of the inventory has passed to the customer upon transfer at which time, the Company receives payment from the customer and recognizes revenue thereon.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company reviews the recoverability of its long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. &nbsp;The estimated future cash flows are based upon, among other things, assumptions about future operating performance, and may differ from actual cash flows. &nbsp;Long-lived assets evaluated for impairment are grouped with other assets to the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other groups of assets and liabilities. &nbsp;If the sum of the projected undiscounted cash flows (excluding interest) is less than the carrying value of the assets, the assets will be written down to the estimated fair value in the period in which the determination is made.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Stock-based Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company accounts for all stock-based payments and awards under the fair value based method.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Stock-based payments to non-employees are measured at the fair value of the consideration received, or the fair value of the equity instruments issued, or liabilities incurred, whichever is more reliably measurable. &nbsp;The fair value of stock-based payments to non-employees is periodically re-measured until the counterparty performance is complete, and any change therein is recognized over the vesting period of the award and in the same manner as if the Company had paid cash instead of paying with or using equity based instruments. &nbsp;The cost of the stock-based payments to non-employees that is fully vested and non-forfeitable as at the grant date is measured and recognized at that date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company accounts for the granting of share purchase options to employees using the fair value method whereby all awards to employees will be recorded at fair value on the date of the grant. &nbsp;The fair value of all share purchase options are expensed over their vesting period with a corresponding increase to additional capital surplus. &nbsp;Upon exercise of share purchase options, the consideration paid by the option holder, together with the amount previously recognized in additional paid-in capital is recorded as an increase to share capital.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>16</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company uses the binomial option pricing model to determine the fair value of all stock based awards classified as liabilities and the Black-Scholes option pricing model to calculate the fair value of share purchase options. &nbsp;Option pricing models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, including the expected price volatility. &nbsp;Changes in these assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>MANAGEMENT&#146;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Equity Financing Timeline</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">Fiscal 2011: &nbsp;40,000 units at US$0.09 per unit = US$3,600</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">Fiscal 2012: &nbsp;None</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">Fiscal 2013: &nbsp;None</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">Fiscal 2014-to-date: None</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Fiscal 2013 Ended 6/30/2013</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc. (Barrier) manufactures and sells fire-rated building materials. Barrier&#146;s primary business is in the United States but through developing licensed manufacturer or distribution partnerships is endeavoring to enter building products markets in Australia, Europe, and South America.<FONT style="font-family:Comic Sans MS,Times New Roman"> </FONT><FONT style="font-family:Courier New">Barrier possesses a proprietary fire resistive material technology (Pyrotite&#174;) and a patented manufacturing process that when applied to building materials their respective fire resistant properties are significantly enhanced. &nbsp;Many of the top multifamily and wood frame commercial builders in the United States utilize Barrier&#146;s fire-rated structural panels in areas where the building code requires the use of a fire-rated building panel.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Barrier manufactures a private label fire rated sheathing product under contract for both LP<SUP>&#174; </SUP>Building Products, Inc. (LP) and MuleHide Products, Inc. (MuleHide). &nbsp;LP introduced a fire rated OSB trademarked LP<SUP>&#174;</SUP> Flameblock<SUP>&#174;</SUP> Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing (LP FlameBlock) and MuleHide has been selling MuleHide FR Deck Panel (FR Deck Panel) to commercial modular building manufacturers since 2004.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s financial statements are filed with both the SEC (USA) and SEDAR (Canada) and are disclosed in US dollars utilizing US generally accepted accounting principles. &nbsp;Barrier&#146;s filings with the SEC consist of quarterly financial statements filed with Form 10-Q and annual audited financial statements filed with Form 10-K. &nbsp;Barrier continues to file the above financial statements with SEDAR in Canada.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>During the current fiscal year period, R&amp;D activity has generally been focused on creating new and improved fire rated wall assemblies. New and improved wall assemblies, tested and listed by Underwriters Laboratory and sanctioned by the International Code Council, are a significant factor in improved sales volume.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:1.2px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><B><U>Sales</U> </B>revenue reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2013 was up 45% to $5,994,994 in comparison to $4,144,769 generated in the same fiscal period in 2012. Total sales volume, as measured by surface volume of product shipped, was 13,243,741 sq ft; an all time high for Barrier for the second year in a row. &nbsp;This is a 37% increase from the 9,687,029 sq. ft. shipped during the previous year. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Shipments into the Residential Roof Deck, Wall Assembly, and Structural Insulated Panel Market Sectors (LP FlameBlock) during the fiscal year increased 51% over shipments in fiscal 2012. &nbsp;LP Flameblock sales were split between the Mid-Atlantic region at 43%, the South at 28%, the Midwest at 15%, and the West at 12%. There were 2% of shipments of LP Flameblock into the Structural Insulated Panel market during this period. &nbsp;Sales into the Commercial Modular Market (FR Deck Panel) increased 11% in comparison to the previous year. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>17</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the past quarter, LP and Barrier elected to extend their existing Supply Agreement through December 31, 2013, with an option to extend through December 31, 2014 with mutual agreement. The agreement provides LP the exclusive opportunity to market Pyrotite&#174; technology based structural wood products in North America as long as minimum sales volumes are met on an annual basis. Sales to the Commercial Modular Market are restricted from the LP Agreement since that market is serviced by MuleHide. LP is the largest producer of Oriented Strand Board (OSB) in the world and believes that Barrier&#146;s Pyrotite&#174; Technology helps them achieve their strategy of providing &#147;value added&#148; OSB products to the building community. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The relationship with LP has increased sales volume to historical levels and Barrier anticipates that sales will continue to grow substantially through the efforts of LP&#146;s sales and marketing team. &nbsp;Reported sales revenue for LP products, include only the charges for treatment services, not the underlying OSB substrate or outbound freight as LP supplies its own OSB substrate and contracts for its own outgoing freight. &nbsp;The &#147;pass through&#148; of the OSB substrate and freight serves to lower reported &#147;top line&#148; sales revenue, but not gross profits since margins on substrate and freight have historically been restricted to handling costs only to help keep prices competitive. &nbsp;For the Commercial Modular market, Barrier purchases OSB from local distributors and invoices the cost of the substrate and outgoing freight to the customer, therefore the cost of the substrate and freight is included in revenue for Commercial Modular shipments.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Gross profit</U></B> for the fiscal period was $709,810 vs. $258,072 in the previous year. The gross margin, as a percentage of sales revenue, doubled from 6% in the prior year to 12% in the current fiscal year. &nbsp;Further improvements in gross margin are anticipated with gains in manufacturing efficiencies provided by improved production technology and efficiencies created by steady and increased sales volumes. Overhead costs will be spread across a larger manufacturing/sales volume base. &nbsp;Barrier is intently focused on improving gross margins.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Cost of sales</U></B><B> </B>increased to $5,285,184 from $3,886,697 in Fiscal 2012. &nbsp;The increase is attributable to the increase in volume produced. &nbsp;Average cost per sq.ft. of production remained consistent with the year-to-date average at $0.40 for the current and prior year. &nbsp;As shipment volumes continue to increase, Barrier expects that the fixed costs included in Cost of Sales will decrease as revenues increase, thus improving gross margins.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Substrate cost and materials/labor were the major expenses in this category. &nbsp;Substrate accounted for $1,558,479 for the fiscal year versus $822,271 in the same period last year. Materials and labor accounted for an additional $2,662,060 in the twelve month period in 2013 versus $2,101,367 in 2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Depreciation on plant and equipment is included in cost of sales category. Depreciation, which has non-cash impact on Barrier&#146;s actual cash flow, increased slightly year-to-date from $295,466 in 2012 to $303,914. &nbsp;The expense reflects depreciation of the new manufacturing line equipment and building expansion. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:1.2px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Administrative expenses</U></B> for Fiscal 2013 decreased to $710,294 from $892,033 in the prior year. &nbsp;The administrative costs per sq. ft. were $0.05 for the fiscal year which was a significant improvement from $0.09 reported in Fiscal 2012. Barrier continues to focus on the positive impact of increased sales volume reducing administrative cost per square foot shipped. As volumes continue to increase, the trend for overall reduction in the average cost of administrative expense per sq.ft. is expected to continue.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Accounting and Audit Fees</U></B> decreased from $100,646 to $91,745. &nbsp;A significant portion of the cost for accounting services is involved with the year-end audited review and publishing of Barrier&#146;s annual financials.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:1.2px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Insurance costs</U></B> have decreased from $80,672 to $65,138. &nbsp;The difference is due to annually adjusted premiums based on larger sales volume discounts. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>18</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Legal fees</U></B> remained stable at $36,985 for the annual period ending June 30, 2013. &nbsp;For the same period in the prior year, legal fees were $36,512. &nbsp;Legal fees were expended on activities related to the year-end Annual General Meeting and in support of protecting Pyrotite&#174; patents and trademark registration as well as for help in the drafting and review of certain business correspondence. &nbsp;Barrier believes protecting its technology and trademarks is an important step in positioning itself to develop strategic partners and potential technology licensees.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Barrier has two US patents, a patent in Australia, and a new patent in Canada. These patents protect the manufacturing and process technology utilized in the production of fire-rated sheathing products utilizing Pyrotite&#174;. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Sales, marketing, and investor relations</U></B> expenses decreased from $44,218 to $34,151 for the year. During the year, there were sales trips directly related to the expansion of product markets.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Barrier&#146;s cost for sales and marketing will continue to decline relative to sales volume as our partners, LP and MuleHide Products, continue to perform more and more of those functions themselves. Barrier remains active in a support role by providing necessary technical sales support but more and more of the day to day market and sales development activities are performed by the capable sales and marketing staffs of LP and MuleHide Products resulting in improved sales but also lower costs for Barrier.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Loss Before Other items</U></B><B> </B>of ($484) is being reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2013, whereas in the same period in 2012, a net loss of ($633,961) was reported.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The significant improvement in loss before other items is a result of increased sales volumes and focus on manufacturing efficiency. It is Barrier&#146;s fundamental belief that sustained increased sales volume, in concert with the existing supply agreements with both MuleHide and LP Products is the best pathway to long-term profitability. Increases in Barrier&#146;s sales volume are expected to follow the improving trend in home building starts in North America.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Other items </U></B>include income and costs not directly related to business operations. &nbsp;Other income items reported during the fiscal year herein includes a foreign exchange gain of $8,116 and other income of $792. &nbsp;To compare, for the same reporting period last year there was a foreign exchange loss of ($8,531) and interest/other income of $1,268. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>In March, 2010, Barrier issued, and sold in a private placement, 15 million shares of stock at the price of $0.10 CDN per share. In addition, the purchasers of the shares were awarded the right to buy an additional share (warrant) at $0.15 CDN. Barrier granted options that were exercisable in Canadian currency, whereas the functional currency of the company is the US dollar. As a result of these transactions, Barrier was required to record these instruments as derivative liabilities which are re-measured to their fair value each reporting period. During the prior fiscal year ended June 30, 2012 the Company reported a fair value gain of $556,762 for the period. &nbsp;The warrants expired, thus no derivative value is recorded for the current period, nor are additional derivative values expected to have to be reported in subsequent periods. &nbsp;Future operating financial performance should be easier to ascertain year over year without the non-cash derivative liability value. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Interest on Long Term Debt has increased from $55,234 to $67,063 for the 12-month reporting period as a result of both bank refinancing and the accumulation of interest on the outstanding convertible debentures.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Net Loss.</U></B><B> &nbsp;</B>A net loss of $58,639 is being reported for the fiscal period ending June 30, 2013, whereas in the same period in 2012, a net loss of $139,696 was reported. Changes in derivative value $556,762 positively affected net income in the prior year reporting period so comparisons period to period are significantly affected by this non-cash item. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>19</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Barrier remains focused on cutting costs and improving efficiencies wherever it can. &nbsp;This includes operating the manufacturing line with maximum efficiency. Keeping a vigilant handle on costs will help keep operational costs as low as possible and enable financial improvements to occur sooner and at lower volumes than previously possible.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Summary of Quarterly Results.</U></B> &nbsp;The following is a summary of the Company&#146;s financial results for the nine most recently completed quarters:</P>

</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=94.6><P style="margin:0px; padding-right:24px; font-family:Courier New" align=right>$Nil</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=88.067><P style="margin:0px; padding-right:24px; font-family:Courier New" align=right>$Nil</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><B><U>New product and market development</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Barrier continues to provide support to LP for new product and market development in activity directed specifically toward applications in areas where wildfires are prevalent. Wildland/ Urban Interface (WUI) zones, which are primarily located in the western US, are areas where special building codes have been developed to help save homes if a brush fire should occur. Becoming certified for use in these applications requires additional product development, including fire testing specific and unique to these fire hazard zones. In addition to these WUI applications, which are primarily associated with limiting the ignition of the exterior of the building, Barrier and LP are cooperating on the development of new, more cost effective, designs of 1 and 2 hour exterior wall systems designed to be used when houses are built in close proximity all over the US. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Barrier and LP have now successfully designed, tested, and UL certified a 2-hr exterior load bearing wall being currently being used in wood-frame commercial/residential buildings of Type III construction. As more architects and specifying engineers become aware of this new design Barrier and LP are confident that considerable sales will result for these projects.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><B><U>Global licensing opportunities</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New">Barrier continues to explore licensed manufacturer or distribution partnership opportunities for Pyrotite&#174; technology in geographies outside of the US.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><B><U>Financial position &amp; financings</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Barrier ended the fiscal year with a working capital deficiency (current assets less current liabilities) of $112,217. &nbsp;Operating cash flow was $314,821 in comparison to ($244,349) for the year ended June 30, 2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>20</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Barrier has a short term revolving line of credit ($100,000) at the local Farmers State Bank of Watkins, in Watkins, Minnesota. &nbsp;As of June 30, 2013 the balance owing on the revolving line of credit was $0 leaving an additional $100,000 available for use. &nbsp;In addition, two convertible debentures in the amount of $150,000 each were established in December 2011. &nbsp;To date, $240,000 has been used on these debentures with an additional $60,000 available for cash flow if needed.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Investing activities resulted in net cash outflow of $155,121 in the current period in comparison to a net cash outflow of $116,363 in the prior year. &nbsp;The cash outflow was the result of the acquisition of plant and equipment capital improvements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Financing activities resulted in net cash outflow of $81,645 in the current year compared to a net cash inflow of $193,493 for last year. &nbsp;The cash outflow resulted from the repayments on long-term debt and obligations under capital lease. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>There is no assurance that Barrier will operate profitably or will generate positive cash flow in the future. In addition, Barrier&#146;s operating results in the future may be subject to significant fluctuations due to many factors not within our control, such as the unpredictability of when customers will order products, the size of customers' orders, the demand for our products, the level of competition or general economic conditions. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the twelve months ended June 30, 2012, the Company issued two convertible promissory debentures to a director and a company controlled by a director. &nbsp;As of June 30, 2013, the company had received $240,000 in respect to these debentures. &nbsp;As needed, the Company will draw the remaining $60,000 available. &nbsp;The debentures bear interest at 12% per annum and are secured by a third charge over the Company&#146;s plant and equipment as well as charge against the Company&#146;s patents. &nbsp;At any time, the notes are convertible into units of the Company at a price of $0.10 per unit. &nbsp;Each unit will consist of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the hold thereof to purchase an additional share for $0.10 for a period of two years from the conversion date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Current and Future Financing Needs</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>At June 30, 2013, the current cash and cash equivalents totaled $179,578; there was $100,000 in available funds to draw on the revolving credit facility, and an additional $60,000 available from the convertible debentures. &nbsp;Over the next twelve months, the Company anticipates that the operation of business will produce an average monthly operating cash flow of $60,000 for a total of $720,000 for the 2014 fiscal year. &nbsp;In addition, over the next 12 months, the Company is required to make payments totaling $140,925 in respect of its long-term and capital lease obligations and $849,537 in respect of accounts payable outstanding as at June 30, 2013. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company bases its estimate of future cash requirements on assumptions that may prove to be wrong and the requirements for cash are subject to factors, some of which are not within the control of the Company, including:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:24px; width:48px; font-family:Symbol; float:left">&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Increased costs of general and administrative expenses</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:24px; width:48px; font-family:Symbol; clear:left; float:left">&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Increased costs of raw materials and freight</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:24px; width:48px; font-family:Symbol; clear:left; float:left">&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Costs associated with the research and development activities</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:24px; width:48px; font-family:Symbol; clear:left; float:left">&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>Costs associated with maintaining property, plant and equipment and intellectual property</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left" align=justify><BR>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Related Party Transactions</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the year ended June 30, 2012, the Company approved the issuance of two convertible debentures to a director and a company controlled by a director in the amount of $300,000. &nbsp;The debentures are being issued in tranches from $10,000 - $50,000 and as at June 30, 2013 the Company had received $240,000 (2012: $200,000) in respect of these debentures. &nbsp;The debentures bear interest at 12% per annum, payable quarterly, and are collateralized by a third charge over the Company&#146;s plant and equipment as well as a charge against the Company&#146;s patents. &nbsp;At any time, the notes are convertible into units of the Company at a price of $0.10 per unit. &nbsp;Each unit will consist of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the holder the right to purchase one additional share for $0.10 for a period of two years from the conversion date. During the year ended June 30, 2013, the Company incurred interest charges of $27,158 (2012: $10,559) on these convertible debentures.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman" align=justify><B>Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman" align=justify>Board of Directors and Stockholders</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman" align=justify>International Barrier Technology Inc.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman" align=justify>We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of International Barrier Technology Inc. as of June 30, 2013 and 2012 and the related consolidated statements of operations and comprehensive loss, cash flows and changes in stockholders&#146; equity for the years then ended. &nbsp;These financial statements are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management. &nbsp;Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman" align=justify>We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). &nbsp;Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. &nbsp;The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting. &nbsp;Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting. Accordingly, we express no such opinion. &nbsp;An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. &nbsp;We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman" align=justify>In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of International Barrier Technology Inc. at June 30, 2013 and 2012 and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman" align=justify><I>/s/ BDO Canada LLP</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Trebuchet MS,Times New Roman">Chartered Accountants</P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 1</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Nature of Operations </U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company develops, manufactures and markets proprietary fire resistant building materials branded as Blazeguard in the United States of America and, as well, the Company owns the exclusive U.S. and international rights to the Pyrotite fire retardant technology.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">These consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (&#147;GAAP&#148;) on a going concern basis, which assumes that the Company will continue to realize its assets and discharge its obligations and commitments in the normal course of operations. Realization values may be substantially different from carrying values as shown and these financial statements do not give effect to adjustments that would be necessary to the carrying values and classification of assets and liabilities should the Company be unable to continue as a going concern. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company was incorporated under the British Columbia Company Act and is publicly traded on the TSX Venture Exchange in Canada (&#147;TSX-V&#148;) and the OTC Bulletin Board in the United States of America. During the years ended June 30, 2013 and June 30, 2012, the Company had assets in each of Canada and the United States of America and generated sales primarily in the United States of America. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 2</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Significant Accounting Policies</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The preparation of financial statements in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses in the reporting period. The Company regularly evaluates estimates and assumptions related to deferred income tax asset valuations, asset impairment, derivative liability, stock based compensation and loss contingencies. The Company bases its estimates and assumptions on current facts, historical experience and various other factors that it believes to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities and the accrual of costs and expenses that are not readily apparent from other sources. The actual results experienced by the Company may differ materially and adversely from the Company&#146;s estimates. To the extent there are material differences between the estimates and the actual results, future results of operations will be affected.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The financial statements have, in management&#146;s opinion, been properly prepared within the framework of the significant accounting policies summarized below:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">a)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Principles of Consolidation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">These consolidated financial statements include the accounts of International Barrier Technology Inc. and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, Pyrotite Coatings of Canada Inc., a Canadian company and Barrier Technology Corporation (&#147;Barrier&#148;), a US company. &nbsp;All inter-company transactions and balances have been eliminated.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Cash and Cash Equivalents</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash and short-term term deposits, redeemable within 90 days of inception, held at Canadian banks.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>28</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 2</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Significant Accounting Policies</U> &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">c)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Inventory</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Inventory is valued by management at the lower of cost on a FIFO (first-in, first-out) basis and net realizable value. &nbsp;In addition, items such as abnormal amounts of idle facility expense, freight, handling and wasted material are recognized as current period charges rather than inventory value. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Plant and Equipment, Trademark and Technology Rights and Depreciation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Plant and equipment and trademark and technology rights are recorded at cost. &nbsp;Depreciation is provided as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 align=center><TR height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=281.4 /><TD width=240 /></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=281.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Manufacturing equipment</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=240><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">straight line over estimated useful lives ranging from 5 years to 30 years.</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=281.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Equipment and furniture</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=240><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">20%- declining balance</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=281.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Computer equipment</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=240><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">30% - declining balance</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=281.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Railway spur</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=240><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">4% - declining balance</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=281.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Equipment under capital lease</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=240><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">20% - declining balance</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=281.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Building under capital lease</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=240><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">straight line over 20 years</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=281.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Patent, trademark and technology rights</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=top width=240><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">straight line over 8 years</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Leasehold improvements are depreciated over the shorter of the lease term or the estimated useful economic life. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">e)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company reviews the recoverability of its long-lived assets whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of such assets may not be recoverable. The estimated future cash flows are based upon, among other things, assumptions about future operating performance, and may differ from actual cash flows. Long-lived assets evaluated for impairment are grouped with other assets to the lowest level for which identifiable cash flows are largely independent of the cash flows of other groups of assets and liabilities. If the sum of the projected undiscounted cash flows (excluding interest) is less than the carrying value of the assets, the assets will be written down to the estimated fair value in the period in which the determination is made. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">f)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Leases</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Leases are classified as capital or operating leases. &nbsp;A lease that transfers substantially all benefits and risks incidental to the ownership of property is classified as a capital lease. &nbsp;At the inception of a capital lease, an asset and an obligation are recorded at an amount equal to the lesser of the present value of the minimum lease payments and the property&#146;s fair value at the beginning of the lease. &nbsp;All other leases are accounted for as operating leases wherein rental payments are expensed as incurred.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">g)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Foreign Currency Translation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The functional currency for the Company&#146;s operations is the US dollar. Monetary assets and liabilities denominated in Canadian dollars are translated into U.S. dollars at the exchange rate prevailing at the end of the year. &nbsp;Non-monetary assets and liabilities are translated at the exchange rate prevailing at the respective transaction dates while revenues and expenses are translated at the average exchange rate during the year. &nbsp;Exchange gains and losses are recognized in the statement of operations. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>29</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 2</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Significant Accounting Policies</U> &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">h)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Research and Development Costs</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Research and development costs are expensed in the year in which they are incurred.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">i)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Basic and Diluted Gain (Loss) per Share </U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Basic net gain per common share is calculated by dividing net gain by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period. &nbsp;Diluted net gain per common share includes both the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period plus the potentially dilutive securities from stock options and warrants outstanding. &nbsp;The number of shares potentially issuable at June 30, 2013 and 2012 upon exercise or conversion of share purchase warrants and share purchase options and the conversion of convertible debentures totalled 8,052,500 and 8,230,000 respectively. These instruments were excluded from the calculation of diluted earnings per share because their effect is anti-dilutive.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; float:left"><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

<STRIKE></STRIKE>

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

j

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">)</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Fair Value Measurements</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The book value of cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued liabilities approximate their fair values due to the short term maturity of those instruments. &nbsp;Based on borrowing rates currently available to the Company under similar terms, the book value of long term debt, convertible debentures and capital lease obligations approximate their fair values. The fair value hierarchy under GAAP is based on three levels of inputs, of which the first two are considered observable and the last unobservable, that may be used to measure fair value which are the following:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:96px; width:162px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Level 1- </P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:162px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities;</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:96px; width:162px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; clear:left; float:left">Level 2 - &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:162px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">observable inputs other than Level I, quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar assets and liabilities in markets that are not active, and model-derived prices whose inputs are observable or whose significant value drivers are observable; and </P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:96px; width:162px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; clear:left; float:left">Level 3 - </P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:162px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">assets and liabilities whose significant value drivers are unobservable by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Certain of the Company&#146;s cash equivalents, consisting of short-term term deposits, are based on Level 2 inputs in the ASC 820 fair value hierarchy.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s long-term debt is based on Level 2 inputs in the ASC 820 fair value hierarchy. &nbsp;Based on the borrowing rates currently available to the Company for bank loans with similar terms and average maturities, the fair value of the long-term debt is $371,926 (2012:$467,850).</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s convertible debentures are based on Level 2 inputs in the ASC 820 fair value hierarchy. &nbsp;The Company calculated the fair value of these instruments by discounting future cash flows using rates representative of current borrowing rates. &nbsp;At June 30, 2013, the convertible debentures had a fair value of $431,022 (2012: $309,185).</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Certain assets and liabilities are measured at fair value on a nonrecurring basis; that is, the instruments are not measured at fair value on an ongoing basis but are subject to fair value adjustments only in certain circumstances (for example, when there is evidence of impairment). &nbsp;There were no assets or liabilities measured at fair value on a nonrecurring basis during the periods ended June 30, 2013 and 2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>30</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 2</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Significant Accounting Policies</U> &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; float:left"><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

<STRIKE></STRIKE>

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

k

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">)</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Accounts Receivable and Concentrations of Credit Risk</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company grants credit to its customers in the normal course of business. Trade receivables are typically non-interest bearing and are initially recorded at cost. Sales to the Company&#146;s recurring customers are generally made on open account terms. Past due status of customer accounts is determined based on how recently payments have been received in relation to payment terms granted. Credit is generally extended based upon an evaluation of each customer&#146;s financial condition, with terms consistent in the industry and no collateral required. Losses from credit sales are provided for in the financial statements and consistently have been within the allowance provided. The allowance is an estimate of the uncollectibility of accounts receivable based on an evaluation of specific customer risks along with additional reserves based on historical and probable bad debt experience. Amounts are written off against the allowance in the period the Company determines that the receivable is uncollectible. The Company has not recorded an allowance for doubtful accounts against its accounts receivable in each of the years ended June 30, 2013 or June 30, 2012. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; float:left"><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

<STRIKE></STRIKE>

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

l

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">)</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Currency Risk</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company holds cash of $686 (2012: $57,190) in Canadian dollars exposing it to a foreign currency exchange risk. &nbsp;During the year ended June 30, 2013, the Company realized a foreign exchange gain of $8,117 (2012: foreign exchange loss of $8,531) as a result of the Company holding cash in Canadian dollars.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; float:left"><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

<STRIKE></STRIKE>

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

m

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">)</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Revenue Recognition</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company recognizes revenue in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board&#146;s (&#147;FASB&#148;) Accounting Standards Codification (&#147;ASC&#148;) 605, &#147;Revenue Recognition&#148;, which requires that: (i) persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (ii) delivery has occurred, (iii) the sales price is fixed and determinable, and (iv) collection is reasonably assured. The Company recognizes revenue when the building supplies have been shipped. </P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company also periodically recognizes revenue on a &#147;bill-and-hold&#148; basis in accordance with the authoritative guidance. &nbsp;Under the Company&#146;s &#147;bill-and-hold&#148; arrangements, at the request of the customer, finished inventory is segregated for future delivery at the customer&#146;s discretion. &nbsp;Title and risk of loss of the inventory has passed to the customer upon segregation, at which time the Company receives payment from the customer and recognizes revenue thereon.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Revenue for LP&#174; FlameBlock Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing includes only the charges for treatment services, not the underlying OSB substrate or outbound freight as the customer supplies its own OSB substrate and contracts for its own outgoing freight.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; float:left"><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

<STRIKE></STRIKE>

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

n

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">)</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Income Taxes</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company follows the liability method of accounting for income taxes. &nbsp;Under this method, current income taxes are recognized for the estimated income taxes payable for the current year. &nbsp;Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognized in the current year for temporary differences between the tax and accounting basis of assets and liabilities as well as for the benefit of losses available to be carried forward to future years for tax purposes. &nbsp;Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are measured using tax rates and laws expected to apply in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. &nbsp;The effect of a change in tax rates on deferred income tax assets and liabilities is recognized in operations in the year of change. &nbsp;A valuation allowance is recorded when it is &#147;more likely-than-not&#148; that a deferred tax asset will not be realized.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>31</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 2</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Significant Accounting Policies</U> &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; float:left"><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

<STRIKE></STRIKE>

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

o

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">)</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Stock-based Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company accounts for all stock-based payments and awards under the fair value based method.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based payments to non-employees are measured at the fair value of the consideration received, or the fair value of the equity instruments issued, or liabilities incurred, whichever is more reliably measurable. The fair value of stock-based payments to non-employees is periodically re-measured until the counterparty performance is complete, and any change therein is recognized over the vesting period of the award and in the same manner as if the Company had paid cash instead of paying with or using equity based instruments. The cost of the stock-based payments to non-employees that is fully vested and non-forfeitable as at the grant date is measured and recognized at that date. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company accounts for the granting of share purchase options to employees using the fair value method whereby all awards to employees will be recorded at fair value on the date of the grant. &nbsp;The fair value of all share purchase options are expensed over their vesting period with a corresponding increase to additional capital surplus. &nbsp;Upon exercise of share purchase options, the consideration paid by the option holder, together with the amount previously recognized in additional paid-in capital is recorded as an increase to share capital. Share purchase options granted to employees are accounted for as liabilities when they contain conditions or other features that are indexed to other than a market, performance or service condition. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company uses the Black-Scholes option pricing model to calculate the fair value of share purchase options and the binomial option pricing model to determine the fair value of all stock based awards classified as liabilities. &nbsp;Option pricing models require the input of highly subjective assumptions, including the expected price volatility. &nbsp;Changes in these assumptions can materially affect the fair value estimate.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; float:left"><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

<STRIKE></STRIKE>

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">

p

</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">)</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements </U></P>
<P style="margin-top:5px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; clear:left" align=justify>New accounting pronouncements are issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) or other standards setting bodies that we adopt according to the various timetables the FASB specifies.&nbsp;The Company does not expect the adoption of recently issued accounting pronouncements to have a significant impact on the Company&#146;s results of operations, financial position or cash flow. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 3</P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">During the year ended June 30, 2013, the Company recorded depreciation expense of $303,914 (2012: $295,466) on its property, plant and equipment. This amount is included in cost of sales in the Statement of Operations</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Depreciation of assets under capital leases included in amortization expense for the year ended June 30, 2013 was $96,073 (2012:&nbsp;&nbsp;$102,068).</P>

<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>33</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:60px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 5</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Convertible Debentures</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:60px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">During the year ended June 30, 2012, the Company approved the issuance of two convertible debentures to a director and a company controlled by a director in the amount of $300,000. &nbsp;The debentures are being issued in tranches from $10,000 - $50,000 and as at June 30, 2013 the Company had received $240,000 (2012: $200,000) in respect of these debentures. &nbsp;The debentures bear interest at 12% per annum, payable quarterly, and are collateralized by a third charge over the Company&#146;s plant and equipment as well as a charge against the Company&#146;s patents. &nbsp;At any time, the notes are convertible into units of the Company at a price of $0.10 per unit. &nbsp;Each unit will consist of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the holder the right to purchase one additional share for $0.10 for a period of two years from the conversion date. During the year ended June 30, 2013, the Company incurred interest charges of $ 27,158 (2012: $10,559) on these convertible debentures.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:60px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 6</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Warrant Liability</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:60px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">During the year ended June 30, 2010, the Company sold 15,000,000 units at $0.10CDN per unit for total proceeds of $1,482,974 ($1,500,000CDN). &nbsp;Each unit consisted of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the holder to purchase an additional common share at $CDN 0.15 for a period of two years. &nbsp;Upon the adoption of the guidance in ASC 815-40-15 which became effective for the fiscal year that commenced July 1, 2009, the Company recorded the warrants issued as derivative liabilities due to their exercise price being denominated in a currency other than the Company&#146;s US dollar functional currency.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:60px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The warrant liability was re-valued at the end of each reporting period with the change in fair value of the derivative liability recorded as a gain or loss in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statements of Operations. &nbsp;The warrant liability was accounted for at its fair value as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="margin-top:0px; font-size:10pt" cellpadding=0 cellspacing=0 align=center><TR height=0 style="font-size:0"><TD width=189.067 /><TD width=107.867 /><TD width=24.6 /><TD width=111.933 /></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=189.067><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom width=107.867><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>June 30, 2013</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=24.6><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px; border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom width=111.933><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=center>June 30, 2012</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=189.067><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=107.867><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=24.6><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=111.933><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
<TR><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=189.067><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Beginning Fair Value</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=107.867><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right>$ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;-</P>
</TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=24.6><P style="margin:0px; padding:0px">&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="margin-top:0px" valign=bottom width=111.933><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right>$ &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;566,762</P>
</TD></TR>

<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Interest on capital leases included in interest on long-term debt for the year ended June 30, 2013 was $12,181 (2012:&nbsp;&nbsp;$15,710).</P>

<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>35</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 9</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Common Stock</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">a)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Escrow:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>At June 30, 2013, there are 48,922 (2012 &#150; 48,922) common shares held in escrow by the Company&#146;s transfer agent, the release which is subject to the approval of the regulatory authorities. As at June 30, 2013, all of these shares held in escrow are issuable but the Company has yet to request their release. &nbsp;These shares have been included in the computation of net loss per share.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Commitments:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based Compensation Plan</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">In November 2005, the Company continued its rolling stock option plan (&#147;the 2005 Rolling Plan&#148;). &nbsp;The 2005 Rolling Plan provides for the granting of stock options to selected directors, officers, employees or consultants in an aggregate amount of up to 10% of the issued and outstanding common shares of the Company. &nbsp;Under the 2005 Rolling Plan, the granting of stock options, exercise prices and terms are determined by the Company's Board of Directors. Options granted to non-executive employees and consultants typically vest in stages over various periods of time while options granted to Directors and executive employees vest immediately upon their grant. The exercise price shall not be less than the Discounted Market Price, which is defined as the last closing price of the common shares before the date of the grant less an applicable discount, as allowed by the regulatory authorities. Options granted under the 2005 Rolling Plan may not exceed &nbsp;a term of 5 years unless the Company achieves classification as a &#147;Tier 1 &#147; issuer in accordance with the policies of the TSX, in which case, the options may be granted for a maximum term of 10 years. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">A summary of the status of the Company&#146;s share purchase option plan as of June 30, 2013 and 2012 and changes during the years ending on those dates is presented below:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
