<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 9</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Common Stock &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:72px; width:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">b)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Commitments: - (cont&#146;d)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Stock-based Compensation Plan &#150; (cont&#146;d)</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>The weighted-average grant date fair value of options granted during the year ended June 30, 2012 was $0.10. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>Subsequent to June 30, 2013, the Company granted 1,177,500 share purchase options to directors, officers, employees and consultants of the Company exercisable at $0.097 US per common share for a period of three years.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Employee Share Purchase Options</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the year ended June 30, 2012, the Company granted a total of 3,840,000 share purchase options to various directors, employees and consultants exercisable at $0.10 per share until May 15, 2015. These options were fully vested at the date of issuance. &nbsp;The fair value of these options was determined to be $115,200, which was recognized in the consolidated statement of operations and comprehensive loss for the year ended June 30, 2012. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>The fair value of the stock options granted was determined using the Black Scholes option pricing model using the following assumptions: expected dividend yield: 0.00%, expected volatility: 116.48%, risk-free interest rate: 0.38%, expected term: 3.00 years.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 10</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><U>Research and Development Costs</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">Research and development expense, included in cost of sales, consists of the following for the years ended June 30, 2013 and 2012. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company evaluates its valuation allowance requirements based on projected future operations. When circumstances change and this causes a change in management&#146;s judgment about the recoverability of future tax assets, the impact of the change on the valuation allowance is reflected in current income. As management of the Company does not currently believe that it is more likely than not that the Company will receive the benefit of this asset, a valuation allowance equal to the future tax asset has been established at both June 30, 2013 and June 30, 2012. </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>As at June 30, 2013, the Company had estimated net operating loss carry-forwards available to reduce taxable income in future years, which were incurred in the United States and Canada and which expire as follows: </P>

<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; page-break-before:always"><B>INTERNATIONAL BARRIER TECHNOLOGY INC.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">June 30, 2013 and 2012</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">(<U>Stated in US Dollars</U>)</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 11</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Income Taxes &#150; (cont&#146;d)</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman"><I>Uncertain Tax Positions</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company has adopted certain provisions of ASC 740, &#147;Income Taxes&#148;, which prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the recognition and measurement of tax positions taken or expected to be taken in income tax returns. The provisions also provide guidance on the de-recognition of income tax assets and liabilities, classification of current and deferred income tax assets and liabilities, and accounting for interest and penalties associated with tax positions.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">The Company files income tax returns in the U.S. and Canadian federal jurisdictions and various state jurisdictions. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s tax returns are subject to tax examinations by U.S. and Canadian federal and state tax authorities until respective statutes of limitation. &nbsp;The Company currently has no tax years under examination. The Company is subject to tax examinations by tax authorities for all taxation years commencing after 2003.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman">At June 30, 2013, the Company does not have an accrual relating to uncertain tax positions. It is not anticipated that unrecognized tax benefits would significantly increase or decrease within 12 months of the reporting date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>Provision has not been made for U.S. or additional foreign taxes on undistributed earnings of foreign subsidiaries. Such earnings have been and will continue to be reinvested but could become subject to additional tax if they were remitted as dividends, or were loaned to the Company affiliate. It is not practicable to determine the amount of additional tax, if any, that might be payable on the undistributed foreign earnings. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; width:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman; float:left">Note 12</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Segmented information and sales concentration</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company operates in one industry segment being the manufacturing and marketing of fire resistant building materials. Substantially all of the Company&#146;s revenues and long-term assets are located in the United States. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>Barrier sells LP&#174; FlameBlock Fire-Rated OSB Sheathing to LP&#174; Building Products (&#147;LP&#148;) and sales to LP accounted for 70% of Fiscal 2013 revenues. &nbsp;Barrier sells MuleHide FR Deck Panel to MuleHide Products (&#147;MuleHide&#148;), Inc. and sales to MuleHide accounted for 30% of Fiscal 2013 revenues. &nbsp;In 2012, sales to LP accounted for 61% of sales revenues and MuleHide accounted for 38%. &nbsp;The amounts receivable from each of these customers at June 30, 2013 is $179,720 and $0 respectively (2012: &nbsp;$89,936 and $17,662 respectively).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:72px; font-family:Arial,Times New Roman" align=justify>The loss of either of these customers or the curtailment of purchases by such customers could have material adverse effects on the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 9. &nbsp;CHANGES IN AND DISAGREEMENTS WITH ACCOUNTANTS ON ACCOUNTING AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">Not applicable </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869008"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 9A. &nbsp;CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B>(a) &nbsp;Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures</B> </P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>As required by Rule 13(a)-15 under the Exchange Act, in connection with this annual report on Form 10-K, under the direction of the Chief Executive Officer, the Company has evaluated its disclosure controls and procedures as of June 30, 2013, and has concluded the disclosure controls and procedures were ineffective as discussed in greater detail below. &nbsp;As of the date of this filing, the Company is still in the process of remediating such material weaknesses in its internal controls and procedures.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B>(b) &nbsp;Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining internal control over financial reporting, as such term is defined in Rule 13a-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Our management evaluated, under the supervision and with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, the effectiveness of its internal control over financial reporting as of June 30, 2013.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Based on its evaluation under the framework in Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework, issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission, management with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer and our Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting was not effective as of June 30, 2013, due to the existence of a significant deficiency constituting a material weakness, as described in greater detail below. &nbsp;A material weakness is a control deficiency, or combination of control deficiencies, such that there is a reasonable possibility that a material misstatement of the annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>In light of this material weakness, the Company performed additional post-closing procedures and analyses in order to prepare the consolidated financial statements included in this report. As a result of these procedures, the Company believes its consolidated financial statements included in this report present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position, results of operations and cash flows for the year ended June 30, 2013.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><I>Limitations on Effectiveness of Controls</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer does not expect that disclosure controls or internal control over financial reporting will prevent all errors and all fraud. A control system, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable, not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the control system are met. &nbsp;Further, the design of a control system must reflect the fact that there are resource constraints, and the benefits of controls must be considered relative to their costs. &nbsp;Because of the inherent limitations in all control systems, no evaluation of controls can provide absolute assurance that all control issues and instances of fraud, if any, within the company have been detected. &nbsp;These inherent limitations include the realities that judgments in decision-making can be faulty, and that breakdowns can occur because of a simple error or mistake. &nbsp;Additional controls can be circumvented by the individual acts of some persons, by collusion of two or more people, or by management override of the controls. &nbsp;The design of any system of controls also is based in part upon certain assumptions about the likelihood of future events, and there can be no assurance that any design will succeed in achieving its stated goals under all potential future conditions; over time, controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. &nbsp;Because of the inherent limitations in a cost-effective control system, misstatements due to error or fraud may occur and not be detected.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>40</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><I>Material Weaknesses Identified</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>In connection with the preparation of the consolidated financial statements for the year ended June 30, 2013, management identified the following material weakness in internal control:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:19.2px; padding-right:19.2px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><I>Our company&#146;s accounting staff does not have sufficient technical accounting knowledge relating to accounting for income taxes and complex US GAAP matters.</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><I>Plan for Remediation of Material Weaknesses</I> </P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>We intend to take appropriate and reasonable steps to make the necessary improvements to remediate this deficiency as resources to do so become available. &nbsp;We intend to consider the results of our remediation efforts and related testing as part of our year-end 2014 assessment of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Such remediation would entail enhancing the training and oversight of the accounting personnel responsible for non-routine transactions involving complex accounting matters and engaging the services of an independent consultant with sufficient expertise in income tax and complex US GAAP matters to assist us in the preparation of our financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-48px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B>(c) &nbsp;Changes in Internal Controls</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>There were no changes in the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting during the fourth quarter of our fiscal year ended June 30, 2013 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869009"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>ITEM 9B. &nbsp;OTHER INFORMATION</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">None</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><I>David J. Corcoran</I>, Director, is a Chartered Accountant and a member of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in British Columbia, Canada, with over twenty-five years of experience in industry and commerce. &nbsp;Prior to 1976, Mr. Corcoran spent over five years gaining experience in marketing, sales and product distribution while he worked in sales with several major companies including Scott Paper and Bristol Myers. &nbsp;His career in accounting began in 1976 when he joined Touche Ross and Company. &nbsp;In 1979, he founded Corcoran and Company, Chartered Accountants. &nbsp;From 1979 to 1990, his firm secured a wide variety of business clients whom he advised regarding their management and business planning. &nbsp;In 1991, he joined the management of the Company on a full-time basis. &nbsp;Mr. Corcoran brings to the organization specific business experience in both sales and public finance. &nbsp;He has been an officer and director of the Company since it inception in 1986 up until he stepped down from Chief Financial Officer effective 11-30-2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><I>Michael D. Huddy</I>, President/CEO and Director, joined the Company in February 1993 as President of the newly-formed US Subsidiary, Barrier Technology Corporation. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy was elected President/CEO of the Company and a Director in July 1994. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy had been in charge of marketing and sales of Blazeguard<FONT style="font-family:Symbol">&#226;</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Courier New"> with Citadel and Weyerhaeuser. &nbsp;He was part of Weyerhaeuser&#146;s research/development team established to develop the Blazeguard</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Symbol">&#226;</FONT><FONT style="font-family:Courier New"> product. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy brings sales, marketing and general management experience. &nbsp;He joined Weyerhaeuser&#146;s Architectural Products Group in 1988, after two years as General Manager of Weyerhaeuser&#146;s Northwest Hardwoods operations in Wisconsin. &nbsp;Before joining Weyerhaeuser, Dr. Huddy worked for Crown Zellerbach Corporation for seven years. &nbsp;Dr. Huddy holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Biological Sciences with a minor in Chemistry from Lake Superior State College; a Masters of Science degree in Resource Administration; and a Ph.D. in Natural Resource Economics with a minor in Business Management from Michigan State University.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><I>Melissa McElwee</I>, Chief Financial Officer, Ms. McElwee joined Barrier in 2003 as the Financial Services Manager for the USA operations where she was responsible for accounting, internal sales, and human resources.&nbsp; She is the General Operations Manager for Barrier.&nbsp; Ms. McElwee is responsible for customer relations, financial management, and production management for the company.&nbsp; She has a strong background in communication, financial analysis, and management.&nbsp; Prior to Barrier, Ms. McElwee held various managerial roles at Principal Financial Group in Iowa.&nbsp; She lead a team of project analysts responsible for developing and maintaining computer programs designed to efficiently process required IRS compliance testing for over 10,000 qualified retirement plans.&nbsp; In addition, Ms. McElwee facilitated external client presentations and internal training programs.&nbsp; Ms. McElwee holds a B.S. in Finance from Iowa State University in Ames, IA.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><I>Lindsey Nauen</I>, Corporate Secretary, received her MBA from the University of Minnesota in 1988. &nbsp;She also received a B.A. in psychology in 1971 and a M.A. in Library Science in 1974. &nbsp;For the last eleven years she has been the owner of Nauen Mobil Accounting, providing accounting and business consulting services to small businesses. &nbsp;In that capacity, she has been providing accounting services to the Company since 1999.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify><I>Victor A. Yates</I>, Director, is a self-employed businessman involved in real estate, construction of multi-family and commercial developments. &nbsp;He holds a degree in Real Estate Appraisal and is a Licensed Real Estate Agent. &nbsp;He 25 years experience in operating a variety of business ventures brings to the Board an entrepreneurial and construction and financial perspective.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>The Directors have served in their respective capacities since their election and/or appointment and will serve until the next Annual General Meeting or until a successor is duly elected, unless the office is vacated in accordance with the Articles/By-Laws of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>The Executive Officers serve at the pleasure of the Board of Directors with management service contracts but without term of office.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>42</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Despite the Company&#146;s Secretary/Administrator spending material portions of this time on businesses other than the Company, the Company believes that he devotes sufficient time to the Company to properly carry out his duties.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>No Director and/or Executive Officer has been the subject of any order, judgment, or decree of any governmental agency or administrator or of any court or competent jurisdiction, revoking or suspending for cause any license, permit or other authority of such person or of any corporation of which he is a Director and/or Executive Officer, to engage in the securities business or in the sale of a particular security or temporarily or permanently restraining or enjoining any such person or any corporation of which he is an officer or director from engaging in or continuing any conduct, practice, or employment in connection with the purchase or sale of securities, or convicting such person of any felony or misdemeanor involving a security or any aspect of the securities business or of theft or of any felony.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>There are no arrangements or understandings between any two or more Directors or Executive Officers, pursuant to which he was selected as a Director or Executive Officer. &nbsp;There are no family relationships between any two or more Directors or Executive Officers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Board of Director Practices</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>All directors hold office until the next meeting of the shareholders of the Company unless they resign or are removed in accordance with the Company&#146;s Articles. &nbsp;Officers are appointed to serve at the discretion of the Board of Directors. &nbsp;The Board of Directors and Committees of the Board schedule regular meetings over the course of the year.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The fundamental objective of the Board is to ensure that it operates in a fashion that maximizes shareholder value over the long term. &nbsp;The Board&#146;s duties and responsibilities are all carried out in a manner consistent with that fundamental objective. &nbsp;The principal duty and responsibility of the Board is to oversee the management and operations of the Company, with the day-to-day management of the business and affairs of the Company delegated by the Board to the CEO and other Executive Officers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Board&#146;s responsibilities include overseeing the conduct of the Company&#146;s business, providing leadership and direction to its management, and setting policies. &nbsp;Strategic direction for the Company is developed through the Board&#146;s annual planning process. &nbsp;Through this process, the Board adopts the operating plan for the coming year, and monitors management&#146;s progress relative to that plan through a regular reporting and review process.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Board has delegated to the President/Chief Executive Officer and the Executive Officers responsibility for the day-to-day management of the business of the Company. &nbsp;Matters of policy and issues outside the normal course of business are brought before the Board for its review and approval, along with all matters dictated by statute and legislation requiring Board review and approval. &nbsp;The President/CEO and the Executive Officers review the Company&#146;s progress in relation to the current operating plan at in-person Board meetings. &nbsp;The Board meets on a regular basis with and without management present. &nbsp;Financial, operational and strategic issues facing the Company are reviewed, monitored and approved at the Board meetings.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Compliance with Section 16(a) of the Exchange Act</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Board of Directors, all Officers, and major shareholders of 10% or more of International Barrier Technology Inc. are in compliance with all reporting requirements of the exchange act with the exception that David Corcoran, reported a stock purchase from 2009 on the Annual Form 5. &nbsp;The shares were reported on SEDAR at the time, but the Form 4 filing was inadvertently missed. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>43</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Code of Ethics</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has not adopted a written &#147;code of ethics&#148; that meets the new United States' Sarbanes-Oxley standards; the Board of Directors believes that existing Canadian standards and procedures is adequate for its purposes. &nbsp;The Company has not seen any need to adopt a written code of ethics on the basis that its corporate culture effectively deters wrongdoing and promotes honest and ethical conduct, full, fair and accurate, timely, and understandable disclosure in reports and documents, the compliance with applicable governmental laws, rules and regulations; the prompt internal reporting of violations of the code; and accountability for adherence to the code.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Corporate Governance</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Director Independence</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Pursuant to Item 407(a)(1)(ii) of Regulation S-K of the Securities Act, our Board of Directors has adopted standards for determining whether a director is independent from management. &nbsp;The Board reviews, consistent with the Company&#146;s corporate governance guidelines, whether a director has any material relationship with the Company that would impair the director&#146;s independent judgment. &nbsp;In summary, an independent director means a person other than an executive officer or employee or any other individual having a relationship which, in the opinion of our directors, would interfere with the exercise of independent judgment in carrying out the responsibilities of a director, and includes any director who accepts compensation from us exceeding $200,000 during any period of twelve consecutive months within the three past fiscal years. &nbsp;Owning shares of our common stock does not preclude a director from being independent. &nbsp;In applying this definition, our board determined that David Corcoran and Victor Yates are independent.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Our board adopted and applied the same definition of independent director to the members of our audit committee. &nbsp;In applying this definition, our board determined that David Corcoran and Victor Yates qualify as an independent director for purposes of Section 10A(m)(3) of the Securities Exchange Act.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Board Meetings and Committees; Annual Meeting Attendance</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During Fiscal 2013, the Board of Directors held seven regularly scheduled meetings, and five special and telephone meetings. &nbsp;For various reasons, Board members may not be able to attend a Board meeting; all Board members are provided information related to each of the agenda items before each meeting, and, therefore, can provide counsel outside the confines of regularly scheduled meetings. &nbsp;No director attended fewer than 75% of the aggregate of: (1) the total number of meetings of the Board of Directors, while he was a Director; and (2) the total number of meetings of committees of the Board of Directors on which the director served. &nbsp;Directors are encouraged to attend annual meetings of our stockholder; three directors physically attended the November 2012 annual shareholders meeting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The attendance records of our Board members during Fiscal 2013 were:</P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:24px; width:50px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt; float:left">(1)</P>

<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:24px; width:50px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt; clear:left; float:left">(2)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:50px; text-indent:-2px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt">Michael Huddy was appointed to the Audit Committee effective 11-30-2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; clear:left"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>44</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Nominating Committee and Compensation Advisory Board</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company does not have a Nominating Committee. &nbsp;The entire Board of Directors is responsible for screening potential director candidates and recommending qualified candidates for nomination as members of the Board of Directors. In evaluating potential director candidates, the Board of Directors considers recommendations of potential candidates from incumbent directors, management and stockholders. &nbsp;Any recommendation submitted by a stockholder to the Board of Directors must include the same information concerning the potential candidate and the stockholder, and must be received in the time frame described herein for the Calendar 2013 Annual meeting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has a Compensation Advisory Board (&#147;Advisory Board&#148;). &nbsp;The Advisory Board consists of David Corcoran, Victor Yates and Martin Lizt. &nbsp;The Advisory Board is responsible for the compensation of the Company&#146;s executive officers and to administer all incentive compensation plans and equity-based plans of the Company, including the plans under which Company securities may be acquired by directors, executive officers, employees and consultants.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Audit Committee</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has an Audit Committee, which recommends to the Board of Directors the engagement of the independent auditors of the Company and reviews with the independent auditors the scope and results of the Company&#146;s audits, the Company&#146;s internal accounting controls, and the professional services furnished by the independent auditors to the Company. &nbsp;The current members of the Audit Committee are: David Corcoran, Mike Huddy and Victor Yates (independent). &nbsp;The Audit Committee met monthly in Fiscal 2013 and has met three times during Fiscal 2014-to-date. &nbsp;Mike was appointed to the Audit Committee at the November 30, 2012 Annual General Meeting to replace Craig Roberts as he stepped down from the Board of Directors effective 11-30-2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company does not have an &#147;audit committee financial expert&#148; serving on its Audit Committee. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s Audit Committee consists of two independent directors and the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer, all of whom are financially literate and very knowledgeable about the Company&#146;s affairs. &nbsp;Because the Company&#146;s structure and operations are straightforward, the Company does not find it necessary to augment its Board with a financial expert.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The audit committee has:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>a. reviewed and discussed the audited financial statements with management;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>b. discussed with the independent auditors the matters required to be discussed by the statement on Auditing Standards No. 61, as amended (AICPA, <I>Professional Standards,</I> Vol. 1. AU section 380), as adopted by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board in Rule 3200T;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>c. received the written disclosures and the letter from the independent accountants required by as adopted by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board in Rule 3526, and has discussed with the independent accountant the independent accountant's independence; and</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:28.8px; text-indent:-28.8px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>d. recommended to the board of directors that the audited financial statements be included in the Company's annual report on Form 10&#150;K for the last fiscal year for filing with the SEC.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Audit Committee recommends to the Board of Directors the engagement of the independent auditors of the Company and reviews with the independent auditors the scope and results of the Company&#146;s audits, the Company&#146;s internal accounting controls, and the professional services furnished by the independent auditors to the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Audit Committee is directly responsible for the appointment, compensation and oversight of auditors; the audit committee has in place procedures for receiving complaints and concerns about accounting and auditing matters; and has the authority and the funding to engage independent counsel and other outside advisors.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>45</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Audit Committee may delegate to one or more designated members of the Audit Committee the authority to grant pre-approvals required by this policy and procedure. &nbsp;The decisions of any Audit Committee member to whom authority is delegated to pre-approve a service shall be presented to the full Audit Committee at its next scheduled meeting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>In accordance with the requirements of the US Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and rules issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission, we introduced a procedure for the review and pre-approval of any services performed by BDO Dunwoody including audit services, audit related services, tax services and other services. &nbsp;The procedure requires that all proposed engagements of DBO Dunwoody LLP for audit and permitted non-audit services are submitted to the audit committee for approval prior to the beginning of any such services.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Shareholder Communications With the Board</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Historically, the Company has adopted an informal process for stockholder communications with the Board by providing an email address and toll-free phone number available on the website: www.intlbarrier.com. &nbsp;Every effort has been made to ensure that the views of stockholders are heard by the Board, or individual directors as applicable, and that appropriate responses are provided to the stockholder in a timely manner. &nbsp;Stockholders wishing to communicate at any time with the Board of Directors, or a specific member of the Board, may do so by writing the Board or a specific member of the Board by delivering correspondence in person or by mail to: The Board of Directors, c/o Lindsey Nauen, Corporate Secretary, 510 4th Street North, Watkins, Minnesota &nbsp;55389. &nbsp;Communication(s) directed to the Board or a specific Board member will be relayed unopened to the intended Board member(s).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Further, Directors&#146; attendance at Annual Meetings can provide shareholders with an opportunity to communicate with Directors about issues affecting the Company. &nbsp;The Company does not have a policy regarding director attendance, but all Directors are encouraged to attend the Annual Meeting of Shareholders. &nbsp;All of our directors attended our Annual Meeting in November 2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869012"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 11. &nbsp;EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Director Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company compensated Directors for their service in their capacity as Directors, $750 per physical meeting up until the decision was made at the November 30, 2012 Annual General Meeting. &nbsp;It was decided to discontinue this payment until further notice. &nbsp;Directors were entitled to reimbursement for reasonable travel and other out-of-pocket expenses incurred in connection with attendance at meetings of the Board of Directors. &nbsp;The Board of Directors may award special remuneration to any Director undertaking any special services on behalf of the Company other than services ordinarily required of a Director. &nbsp;During Fiscal 2013/2012/2011, Directors were paid $3,000, and $9,000, $17,250 for attending meetings, respectively. During the year ended June 30, 2013, no member of the Board of Directors were granted common share purchase options.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Executive Officer Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The following table sets forth the summary of compensation earned during Fiscal 2013 and Fiscal 2012 by the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer and its other named Executive Officers. &nbsp;The following table excludes Directors&#146; Fees paid to Executive Officers who are also Directors; refer to Table No. 6.</P>

<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-2px; text-indent:24px; width:51px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt; clear:left; float:left">(2)</P>

<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-96px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Director Compensation</U></P>

<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:33.6px; text-indent:-33.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(1) &nbsp;The determination of value of option awards is based upon the grant date fair value determined by either binomial or Black-Scholes Option pricing model, details and assumptions of which are set out in Notes 2 and 9 to the consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Stock Options</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company grants stock options to Directors, Executive Officers and employees/consultants; refer to ITEM #11, &#147;Stock Options&#148; and Tables 5/6/7/8/9.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Stock Options Granted/Expired During The Most Recently Completed Fiscal Year</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the most recently completed fiscal year, no incentive stock options were granted to Executive Officers, Directors, employees/consultants. &nbsp;The Company has no equity or non-equity incentive plans. &nbsp;837,500 stock options previously granted to Executive Officers and Directors were cancelled, forfeited, or expired un-exercised; and 140,000 stock options previously granted to employees and/or consultants were cancelled, forfeited, or expired un-exercised.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Option Exercises and Stock Vested</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During Fiscal 2013 ended 6/30/2013, there were no exercises of stock options, 3,252,000 outstanding stock options, and the Company made no stock awards.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Michael Huddy, President/CEO; Written Management Agreement</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Michael Huddy provides his services pursuant to a management agreement dated 2/13/1993; the terms of the agreement have been revised although no new formal agreement has been signed. &nbsp;The current terms require that Mr. Huddy provide full-time service to Barrier in an executive capacity (CEO) and to be fully responsible for Barrier&#146;s activities in the USA. &nbsp;The original agreement was for a term of four years but was to renew automatically ever two years unless written notice of the intent to terminate was given by either party to the other. &nbsp;Terms of compensation are to be given prior to any renewal period.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The employment agreement specifies employer termination provisions including: material breach of any provision of the contract; inability to perform the duties under the agreement; fraud or serious neglect or misconduct; personal bankruptcy.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The duties are complete as to those of a Chief Executive Officer (President) and include: Administration of the day to day affairs of the Employer Development of Financial, manufacturing, and marketing plans; Communication with Employer and Shareholders on a timely basis; and, Formulation and execution of a proposed budget approved by the Employer. &nbsp;The Employment Agreement contains a Confidentiality Provision that precludes the sharing of confidential information to third parties not requiring the information to conduct business with Barrier. &nbsp;The confidentiality provision extends beyond the time limit of the agreement until the information or knowledge becomes part of the public domain.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>48</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Change of Control Remuneration</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has no plans or arrangements in respect of remuneration received or that may be received by Executive Officers of the Company in Fiscal 2014 to compensate such officers in the event of termination of employment (as a result of resignation, retirement, change of control) or a change of responsibilities following a change of control, where the value of such compensation exceeds $100,000 per Executive Officer.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Other Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>No Executive Officer/Director received &#147;other compensation&#148; in excess of the lesser of $25,000 or 10% of such officer's cash compensation, and all Executive Officers/Directors as a group did not receive other compensation which exceeded $25,000 times the number of persons in the group or 10% of the compensation.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Bonus/Profit Sharing/Non-Cash Compensation</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Except for the stock option program discussed in ITEM #6.E., the Company has no material bonus or profit sharing plans pursuant to which cash or non-cash compensation is or may be paid to the Company's Directors or Executive Officers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Pension/Retirement Benefits</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>No funds were set aside or accrued by the Company during Fiscal 2013 to provide pension, retirement or similar benefits for Directors or Executive Officers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869013"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 12. &nbsp;SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><I>Securities authorized for issuance under equity compensation plans</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">We have no long-term incentive plans.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The following table summarizes certain information regarding our equity compensation plan as at June 30, 2013:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>49</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company has adopted a rolling stock option plan (&#147;the 2005 Rolling Plan&#148;). &nbsp;The 2005 Rolling Plan provides for the granting of stock options to selected directors, officers, employees or consultants in an aggregate amount of up to 10% of the issued and outstanding common shares of the Company. &nbsp;Under the 2005 Rolling Plan, the granting of stock options, exercise prices and terms are determined by the Company's Board of Directors. Options granted to non-executive employees and consultants typically vest in stages over various periods of time while options granted to Directors and executive employees vest immediately upon their grant. The exercise price shall not be less than the Discounted Market Price, which is defined as the last closing price of the common shares before the date of the grant less an applicable discount, as allowed by the regulatory authorities. Options granted under the 2005 Rolling Plan may not exceed a term of 5 years unless the Company achieves classification as a &#147;Tier 1&#148; issuer in accordance with the policies of the TSX, in which case, the options may be granted for a maximum term of 10 years.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The following table lists all persons/companies the Company is aware of as being the beneficial owner of 5% or more of the common shares of the Company. &nbsp;&nbsp;It also lists all Directors and Executive Officers who beneficially own the Company's voting securities and the amount of the Company's voting securities owned by the Directors and Executive Officers as a group.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>Escrowed Common Shares</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>On 5/15/1987, the Company issued 296,500 shares of &#147;Principal Escrow&#148;&nbsp;common stock at CDN$0.01 per share. &nbsp;Effective 11/24/2004, 124,530 of these shares were cancelled and returned to the treasury. &nbsp;48,922 of these shares are still escrowed and outstanding. &nbsp;On 8/31/2012, these are held:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Continental Appraisals Ltd.................................... &nbsp;&nbsp;6,115 shares</P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Corcoran Enterprises Ltd...................................... &nbsp;42,807 shares</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Pursuant to a performance escrow agreement dated 2/24/1992 between the Company and certain escrow Shareholders (the &#147;Escrow Agreement&#148;), 48,922 common shares of the Company (the &#147;Escrow Shares&#148;) are held in escrow with Pacific Corporate Trust Company of Vancouver, British Columbia. &nbsp;The Escrow Shares are held by Corcoran Enterprises Ltd. (&#147;Corcoran&#148;), a private company owned by David Corcoran, a director of the Company and Continental Appraisals Ltd. (&#147;Continental&#148;), a private company owned by Victor Yates, a director of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Pursuant to the terms of the Escrow Agreement, the Escrow Shares were to have been surrendered for cancellation on 2/24/2002; however, the Escrow Shares have not been cancelled. &nbsp;The Company has received acceptance in principle from the TSX Venture Exchange (&#147;TSX&#148;) to cancel the Escrow Shares not held by Officers/Director, and have the shares held by Officers/Directors reinstated and made subject to a TSX Tier 2 Surplus Escrow Agreement (the &#147;New Escrow Agreement&#148;) with a six-year time release formula (described below). &nbsp;Conversion of performance escrow shares to time release escrow shares, as contemplated, is permitted under TSX and British Columbia Securities Commission (&#147;BCSC&#148;) policies relating to escrow shares held under previous escrow regimes such as the BCSC&#146;s Local Policy Statement 3-07.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Final approval of the conversion to a time-release formula is, in the Company&#146;s case, subject to the Company obtaining shareholder approval for the reinstatement and conversion to time-release escrow and complying with all other applicable TSXV and BCSC policies related to the reinstatement and conversion.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Following approval by the Company&#146;s shareholders, the TSXV (12/9/2004), and the BCSC, the Company and the escrow shareholders entered into the New Escrow Agreement. &nbsp;Under the terms of the New Escrow Agreement, the Escrow Shares and will be released as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;5% (1/20 of total Escrow Shares) six months from date of TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;5% (1/19 of remaining Escrow Shares) 12 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;5% (1/18 of remaining Escrow Shares) 18 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;5% (1/17 of remaining Escrow Shares) 24 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (1/8 of remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;30 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (1/7 of remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;36 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (1/6 of remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;42 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (1/5 of remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;48 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (1/4 of remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;54 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (1/3 of remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;60 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (1/2 of remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;66 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-134.4px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>&nbsp;10% (all remaining Escrow Shares) &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;72 months from TSXV Acceptance</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>If the Company becomes a Tier 1 issuer under the policies of the TSXV prior to the expiration of the 72-month release period set out above, the release schedule set out above will be amended to comply with the applicable Tier 1 release schedule, resulting in an accelerated release of any securities remaining in escrow, with such securities being released as if the Company had originally been classified as Tier 1 issuer. &nbsp;The securities of Tier 1 issuers held under surplus security escrow agreements are released over a three-year period, with 10% of the securities being released on TSX acceptance and 15% being released every six months thereafter.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>51</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Unless otherwise expressly permitted in the New Escrow Agreement, the Escrow Shares may not be sold, transferred, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise dealt with in any way. &nbsp;Pursuant to the terms of the New Escrow Agreement, the Escrow Shares may be transferred within escrow to an individual who is a director or senior officer of the Company or of a material operating subsidiary of the Company, subject to the approval of the Company&#146;s board of directors, or to a person or company that before the proposed transfer holds more than 20% of the voting rights attached to the Company&#146;s outstanding securities, or to a person or company that after the proposed transfer will hold more than 10% of the voting rights attached to the Company&#146;s outstanding securities and that has the right to elect or appoint one or more directors or senior officers of the Company or of any of its material operating subsidiaries. &nbsp;The Escrow Shares may also be pledged, mortgaged or charged to a financial institution as collateral for a loan. &nbsp;No Escrow Shares may be transferred or delivered to the financial institution for this purpose and the loan agreement must provide that the Escrow Securities will remain in escrow if the lender realizes on the security to satisfy the loan.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Pursuant to the terms of the New Escrow Agreement, upon the bankruptcy of an escrow shareholder, the Escrow Shares of that shareholder held in escrow may be transferred within escrow to the trustee in bankruptcy or other person legally entitled to such securities. &nbsp;Upon the death of an escrow shareholder, all securities of the deceased holder will be released from escrow to the deceased holder&#146;s legal representative.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Subject to certain limited exceptions, escrow shareholders retain all voting rights attached to their Escrow Shares. &nbsp;The New Escrow Agreement provides that the Escrow Shares will be cancelled if the asset, property or business in consideration of which the Escrow Shares were issued is lost or abandoned, or the operations or development of such asset, property or business is discontinued.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>At the Annual Shareholders&#146; Meeting, 12/9/2004, disinterested shareholders approved an ordinary resolution authorizing the reinstatement of the Escrow Shares and the adoption of the New Escrow Agreement by the Company and the escrow shareholders. &nbsp;Disinterested shareholders for the purpose of voting on the resolution include all shareholders of the Company other than David Corcoran and Victor Yates, and their affiliates and associates. &nbsp;A total of 3,449,253 shares held by David Corcoran, Victor Yates, and their affiliates and associates, were therefore not be counted for the purpose of determining whether the required level of shareholder approval has been obtained.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Securities authorized for issuance under equity compensation plans.</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">&nbsp;--- No Disclosure Necessary ---</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><B><U>Stock Options</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The terms of incentive options granted by the Company are done in accordance with the rules and policies of the TSX Venture Exchange, including the number of common shares under option, the exercise price and expiry date of such options, and any amendments thereto. &nbsp;The Company adopted a formal written stock option plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;) on 12/12/2003.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Such &#147;terms and conditions&#148;, including the pricing of the options, expiry and the eligibility of personnel for such stock options; and are described below.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Number of Shares Reserved</U>. &nbsp;The number of common shares that may be issued pursuant to options granted under the Plan may not exceed 10% of the issued and outstanding shares of the Company from time to time at the date of granting of options (including all options granted by the Company under the Plan).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Maximum Term of Options</U>. &nbsp;The term of any options granted under the Plan is fixed by the Board of Directors and may not exceed five years from the date of grant, or ten years if the Company is classified as a &#147;Tier 1&#148; issuer under the policies of the TSX Venture Exchange. &nbsp;The options are non-assignable and non-transferable.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>52</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Exercise Price</U>. &nbsp;The exercise price of options granted under the Plan is determined by the Board of Directors, provided that it is not less than the discounted market price, as that term is defined in the TSX Venture Exchange policy manual or such other minimum price as is permitted by the TSX Venture Exchange in accordance with the policies from time to time, or, if the shares are no longer listed on the TSX Venture Exchange, then such other exchange or quotation system on which the shares are listed or quoted for trading.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Reduction of Exercise Price</U>. &nbsp;The exercise price of stock options granted to insiders may not be decreased without disinterested shareholder approval, as described below.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Termination</U>. &nbsp;Any options granted pursuant to the Plan will terminate generally within 90 days of the option holder ceasing to act as a director, officer, or employee of the Company or any of its affiliates, and within generally 30 days of the option holder ceasing to act as an employee engaged in investor relations activities, unless such cessation is on account of death. &nbsp;If such cessation is on account of death, the options terminate on the first anniversary of such cessation. &nbsp;If such cessation is on account of cause, or terminated by regulatory sanction or by reason of judicial order, the options terminate immediately. &nbsp;Options that have been cancelled or that have expired without having been exercised shall continue to be issuable under the Plan. &nbsp;The Plan also provides for adjustments to outstanding options in the event of any consolidation, subdivision, conversion or exchange of Company&#146;s shares.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Administration</U>. The Plan is administered by the Board of Directors of the Company or senior officer or employee to which such authority is delegated by the Board from time to time.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><U>Board Discretion</U>. The Plan provides that, generally, the number of shares subject to each option, the exercise price, the expiry time, the extent to which such option is exercisable, including vesting schedules, and other terms and conditions relating to such options shall be determined by the Board of Directors of the Company or senior officer or employee to which such authority is delegated by the Board from time to time and in accordance with TSX Venture Exchange policies. &nbsp;The number of option grants, in any twelve-month period, may not result in the issuance to any one optionee which exceed 5% of the outstanding common shares of the Company (unless the Company is a Tier 1 issuer and has obtained the requisite disinterested shareholder approval), or the issuance to a consultant or an employee engaged in investor relations activities which exceed 2% of the outstanding common shares of the Company. &nbsp;Disinterested shareholder approval will be sought in respect of any material amendment to the Plan.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>53</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The names of the Directors/Senior Management/employees/consultants of the Company to whom outstanding stock options have been granted and the number of common shares subject to such options is set forth in the following table, as well as the total number of options outstanding.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Subsequent to fiscal year-end, on 8/2/2013, the Company granted stock options to directors, officers, employees and consultants of the Company, exercisable to acquire up to 1,177,500 common shares of the Company, at an exercise price of $0.097 per common share on the date of grant, expiring on August 2, 2016.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869014"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 13. &nbsp;CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED TRANSACTIONS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>David Corcoran, Administrator/Director</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Mr. Corcoran was compensated for his managerial services to the Company indirectly through Corcoran Enterprises Ltd., a private company controlled by Mr. Corcoran. &nbsp;During Fiscal 2013/2012, $12,500 and $50,000 were paid/accrued to Corcoran Enterprises Ltd., respectively. &nbsp;Mr. Corcoran resigned as Chief Financial Officer on 11/30/2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:1.2px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the twelve months ended June 30, 2012, the Company issued a convertible debenture to a company controlled by Mr. Corcoran in the amount of $150,000. The Company is drawing on this debenture in tranches of between $10,000-50,000 and as of June 30, 2013, the company had received $110,000 in respect of this debenture. &nbsp;The debenture bears interest at 12% per annum and is secured by a third charge over the Company&#146;s plant and equipment as well as charge against the Company&#146;s patents. &nbsp;At any time, the notes are convertible into units of the Company at a price of $0.10 per unit. &nbsp;Each unit will consist of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the holder thereof to purchase an additional share for $0.10 for a period of two years from the conversion date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Michael Huddy, President/CEO</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:1.2px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>During the twelve months ended June 30, 2012, the Company issued a convertible debenture to a company controlled by Mr. Huddy, director, in the amount of $150,000. The Company is drawing on this debenture in tranches of between $10,000-50,000 and as of June 30, 2013, the company had received $130,000 in respect of this debenture. &nbsp;The debenture bears interest at 12% per annum and is secured by a third charge over the Company&#146;s plant and equipment as well as charge against the Company&#146;s patents. &nbsp;At any time, the notes are convertible into units of the Company at a price of $0.10 per unit. &nbsp;Each unit will consist of one common share and one common share purchase warrant entitling the holder thereof to purchase an additional share for $0.10 for a period of two years from the conversion date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New" align=center>54</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<HR style="margin-bottom:9.6px; padding-top:9.6px" noshade size=1.333>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Other than described above, there have been no transactions since 6/30/2012, or proposed transactions, which have materially affected or will materially affect the Company in which any Director, Executive Officer, or beneficial holder of more than 10% of the outstanding common stock, or any of their respective relatives, spouses, associates or affiliates has had or will have any direct or material indirect interest.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869015"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify><B><U>ITEM 14. &nbsp;PRINCIPAL ACCOUNTANT FEES AND SERVICES</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>Professional accounting services were rendered by BDO Canada LLP for Fiscal 2013 and Fiscal 2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Audit Fees</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The aggregate fees billed for professional services rendered by the Company&#146;s principal accountant for the audit of the Company&#146;s annual financial statements incurred in the fiscal years ended 6/30/2013 and 6/30/2012 were $64,905 CDN and $80,884 CDN<B>,</B> respectively.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Audit Related Fees</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company incurred no audit related fees during fiscal years ended 6/30/2013 and 6/30/2012.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>Tax Fees</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company incurred tax fees of $Nil and $6,200 CDN during fiscal years ended 6/30/2013 and 6/30/2012 for professional services rendered by the Company&#146;s principal accountant for tax compliance, tax advice and tax planning.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman"><U>All Other Fees</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman" align=justify>The Company incurred no other fees during the last two fiscal years for services rendered by the Company&#146;s principal accountant.</P>
<A NAME="_Toc367869016"></A><P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-105.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">32. &nbsp;Section 1350 Certifications &#150; <A HREF="ex321.htm"><FONT style="color:#0000FF"><U>Huddy</U></FONT></A></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-105.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<A HREF="ex322.htm"><FONT style="color:#0000FF"><U>McElwee</U></FONT></A></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-105.6px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">99. &nbsp;Additional Exhibits: &nbsp;No Disclosure Necessary</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Courier New,Times New Roman">101.INS<SUP>(1)</SUP>: &nbsp;XBRL Instance Document</P>
